item.title: Final Fantasy IX Designer Toshiyuki Itahana Leaves Square Enix
item.content:encoded:
Toshiyuki Itahana, the man behind Final Fantasy IX's iconic character designs, has departed Square Enix in order to become a freelance artist and illustrator.

In a post on Japanese platform Note (which is in both Japanese and English and which was spotted by ResetEra user Xenosaga), Itahana says he left Square Enix following a period of "thinking seriously about preparing [himself] to continue drawing for many years to come". His departure actually came at the end of 2025.

Itahana goes on to say that while he feels "deeply grateful" towards those who celebrated Final Fantasy IX for the JRPG's 25th anniversary last year, completing the "illustration work and supervision" for the occasion led him to "draw a line under this chapter and take on new challenges".

In conclusion to his post, Itahana says he's hoping to "continue creating a wide variety of new artwork" as a freelancer and expresses his "heartfelt gratitude" to former colleagues both at Square Enix and elsewhere.

As well as Final Fantasy IX, Itahana has worked on a number of other Square Enix projects, including the likes of Final Fantasy XIV's Dawntrail expansion, where he provided character concept art (but nothing beyond that, so I won't blame Dawntrail on him).

He's also worked on the Final Fantasy: Crystal Chronicles games, as well as projects like Chrono Cross: The Radical Dreamers Edition and 2022 racer Chocobo GP. Hopefully, we'll get to see his art in many more games to come.

As for Final Fantasy IX, the RPG's anniversary has come and gone with nary a mention of the long-rumored remake. It is, of course, still possible that the project is on the way, but the 25th anniversary would have been the perfect time to reveal it if so. I wouldn't hold my breath, personally.

We'll have to wait and see what lies in Itahana's future, but whatever it is, it'll probably be outside of Square Enix's purview. Stay tuned for more.

item.title: Tomba! Special Edition Switch 2 Version Shadowdropped by Limited Run
item.content:encoded:
Limited Run Games has shadowdropped a version of remastered platformer Tomba! Special Edition on Switch 2, and it comes complete with a host of improvements specific to the platform as well.

As revealed by Limited Run on Bluesky, Tomba! Special Edition's Switch 2 version features "increased resolution", "improved performance", and "higher quality assets", as well as a "downsampled display mode". If you've got a Switch 2, this sounds like the perfect way to experience the game.

Unfortunately, it doesn't look like owners of the game on Switch 1 will get any kind of upgrade or even a discount, at least according to a couple of users in Limited Run's replies on X. Limited Run itself has been quiet about whether there's an upgrade or not, so it's safe to assume you'll have to buy this one again.

If you're not familiar with Tomba!, it's a rather curious game from the halcyon days of the original PlayStation, having launched in Japan in 1997, followed by a release in America and Europe the following year.

The game is essentially a Metroidvania platformer that follows the titular Tomba, a feral child who must defeat a battalion of pigs in order to recover a sacred bracelet belonging to his grandfather.

To do so, he'll have to explore a large non-linear map filled with areas to explore in both the foreground and background, as well as quests to complete in the course of exploration.

Since release, Tomba!, which was released as Tombi! in Europe, has attracted a cult following, leading to the launch of a sequel, Tomba! 2: The Evil Swine Return, in 1999. The sequel netted itself a release for modern systems, including the Switch 2, in December last year.

You can check out Tomba! Special Edition right now on Switch 2. Stay tuned for more.
